Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A microscopic electronic chip with sensors that can be implanted into living cells to monitor events in real time
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to provide researchers and educators a powerful device to monitor biochemical reactions and physical conditions inside living cells in real time. The probe, which is microscopic in size and powered by incoming light, will be inserted into living cells and will report parameters such as pH and concentration of selected molecules via radio transmissions to a nearby receiver. The transmission will contain both the identity of each cell and the parameter(s) being recorded-hence it will be possible to monitor many cells simultaneously. The ?radio p-Chip? will greatly advance the science of probing cell physiology and create a new area in basic and applied research by providing scientists the ability to study localized functions within living cells. As such, it will be a powerful new tool for advancing knowledge in the fields of mechanisms of disease, drug discovery, and control of biochemical functions, metabolism and other areas. The radio p-Chip and receivers are projected to be low enough in cost that they will also become scientific tools for students to study cell physiology and thus become incorporated into educational curricula.

The proposed project will result in a system that will, for the first time in history, allow scientists to monitor conditions in a living cell with a device that will not interfere with normal functions including movement. The system will be based the current p-Chip, the world?s smallest microtransponder that continuously emits a radio signal with an identification number (ID) when illuminated with light. The p-Chip is used today to tag, track and authenticate a wide variety of objects. In order to realize the radio p-Chip, the current version of the chip will be shrunk by a factor of 10, and a variety of sensors will be added to its surface. Once complete, the radio p-Chip will be able to alternately transmit its ID and sensor value continuously to a nearby receiver. The receiver will process the signal for further use by the operator. In parallel, a series of tools will be developed to reliably implant the chips into living cells. In order to accomplish the goals of the project, PharmaSeq will combine leading edge technologies in semiconductor device design and fabrication, advanced sensor technology, digital and analogue electronics, optics and software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the early invention of microscopes scientists and laymen alike have wondered what activities, both physical and chemical occur in living cells. The main objective of this project has been to design and demonstrate the feasibility of designing and placing a small electronic device into a living cell. The device would then be capable of transmitting a serial number (ID) to identify the cell along with the value of a sensor for a parameter such as temperature. By using multiple devices, each with a unique ID for each cell, it would then be possible to monitor a population of cells in real time. This represents a significant improvement over current methods that use dyes or very fine wires to monitor cell physiology. The new device, which we call a “radio p-Chip”, would have broad application in studies of cell physiology, drug discovery and development, agriculture and education.

The starting point for the work support by NSF was PharmaSeq’s p-Chip, a small (0.5 mm or 0.25 mm square) semiconductor chip (see Image 1) that was originally developed for genetic applications and for tagging small animals such as social insects and laboratory animals. p-Chips are light-activated and function by harvesting energy from a specialized laser reader that rapidly decodes the ID of each chip using a radio signal emitted from antennae on the device.

In order to design a radio p-Chip it was necessary to: 1) greatly reduce the size of the p?Chip to cellular dimensions; 2) add temperature sensing circuitry to the device; 3) design an alternate method to transmit the ID since very small antennas are inefficient; and 4) demonstrate how to implant a small silicon chip into an embryo. In addition, the project was extended by NSF with two commercialization supplements to provide larger p-Chips that incorporate temperature sensing for the more traditional applications of cold chain management of samples used in biorepositories. Each of these objectives accomplished during the course of the project.

As noted, the traditional p-Chip is 0.5 mm or 500 mμ on a side. PharmaSeq has designed and produced prototypes on multi program wafers (MPW) that are 50 mμ on a side. We have also demonstrate functionality of temperature sensing by adding appropriate circuitry to various versions of p-Chips. These chips report temperatures in real time over physiological ranges. Additional versions produced for the supplement periods have been shown to report temperatures from liquid nitrogen (-196? C) to ambient conditions. A challenging part of this work has been to switch from a traditional radio frequency antennae to using light to transmit the data from the p-Chip. This has been accomplished by redesigning the chip and substituting a very small (10 micron) light-emitting diode (LED) in place of the antennae. This micro LED is bonded to the surface of the radio p-Chip to serve as a beacon to transmit information that is decoded to determine the chip’s ID.  Finally, we have been able to successfully implant p-Chips into embryos (see Image 2).

The work has proceeded with a number of commercial partners who have contributed leading edge technology to the project, some of which has been very challenging. The successful completion of this, along with development of manipulation methods will make it possible to place radio p-Chips into a living cells and monitor changes in physiology over time (milliseconds to hours and days). PharmaSeq is continuing development work on the radio p-Chip in anticipation for commercial deployment.


Last Modified: 03/21/2018
Modified by: Wlodek Mandecki

  • An implanted p-Chip emerges from an embryo (left). The non treated embryo is shown on the right.
    Julie Drawbridge, Dept. of Biology & Behavioral Neuroscience, Rider University, Lawrenceville, NJ
    Copyrighted
    Wlodek Mandecki
    p-Chip implanted in Xenopus laevis embryo
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Since the early invention of microscopes scientists and laymen alike have wondered what activities, both physical and chemical occur in living cells. The main objective of this project has been to design and demonstrate the feasibility of designing and placing a small electronic device into a living cell. The device would then be capable of transmitting a serial number (ID) to identify the cell along with the value of a sensor for a parameter such as temperature. By using multiple devices, each with a unique ID for each cell, it would then be possible to monitor a population of cells in real time. This represents a significant improvement over current methods that use dyes or very fine wires to monitor cell physiology. The new device, which we call a "radio p-Chip", would have broad application in studies of cell physiology, drug discovery and development, agriculture and education. The starting point for the work support by NSF was PharmaSeq?s p-Chip, a small (0.5 mm or 0.25 mm square) semiconductor chip (see Image 1) that was originally developed for genetic applications and for tagging small animals such as social insects and laboratory animals. p-Chips are light-activated and function by harvesting energy from a specialized laser reader that rapidly decodes the ID of each chip using a radio signal emitted from antennae on the device. In addition, the project was extended by NSF with two commercialization supplements to provide larger p-Chips that incorporate temperature sensing for the more traditional applications of cold chain management of samples used in biorepositories. Each of these objectives accomplished during the course of the project. As noted, the traditional p-Chip is 0.5 mm or 500 mμ on a side. PharmaSeq has designed and produced prototypes on multi program wafers (MPW) that are 50 mμ on a side. We have also demonstrate functionality of temperature sensing by adding appropriate circuitry to various versions of p-Chips. These chips report temperatures in real time over physiological ranges. Additional versions produced for the supplement periods have been shown to report temperatures from liquid nitrogen (-196? C) to ambient conditions. A challenging part of this work has been to switch from a traditional radio frequency antennae to using light to transmit the data from the p-Chip. This has been accomplished by redesigning the chip and substituting a very small (10 micron) light-emitting diode (LED) in place of the antennae. This micro LED is bonded to the surface of the radio p-Chip to serve as a beacon to transmit information that is decoded to determine the chip?s ID. Finally, we have been able to successfully implant p-Chips into embryos (see Image 2). The work has proceeded with a number of commercial partners who have contributed leading edge technology to the project, some of which has been very challenging. The successful completion of this, along with development of manipulation methods will make it possible to place radio p-Chips into a living cells and monitor changes in physiology over time (milliseconds to hours and days).
